title: Update jsHint config
body:
Although `__proto__` can be misused, it’s now [part of the ES 2015 spec](http://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-object.prototype-object). JsHint seems to lag behind a little – it still issues a warning even if `esnext` is on.

http://stackoverflow.com/a/29254531/2816199

title: componentDidUpdate is missing in react style guide?
body: The react style guide doesn't contain `componentWillUpdate`. Should it be added after `componentWillUpdate`? Thanks.

title: added trailing comma
body:
In some parts of this style guide, trailing commas are not used for other examples outside the comma section.

According to the [comma section](https://github.com/arianf/javascript#19.2) of this style guide, trailing commas should be used. But outside of that section, it is commonly not used in this style guide.

I think for consistency, when the section/topic of the style guide is not focused on the trailing comma's, they should be used. Especially because it is confusing to see a good example that doesn't include the trailing comma.

title: Create package eslint-config-airbnb
body:
This is a sharable ESLint config package. We could optionally just use our eslint config as the package `main` for `airbnb-style` but it'd be nicer for everyone if the eslint package had a cool name.

Solves for issue #349

title: Add standalone ESLint shareable config
body:
Hello.
In [ESLint 0.21.0 released](http://eslint.org/blog/2015/05/eslint-0.21.0-released/) they introduces such thing as [shareable config](http://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/shareable-configs.html).
It provide teams import external configs as npm packages. 
What do you think about publishing ESLint config as [standalone npm packadge](https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=eslintconfig), like "eslint-config-airbnb"?

This allows one to omit parens whenever it fits into a single line, which is similar to our if statement rules.

Fixes #281

title: add eslint rules for JSX style from issue #345
body:
Adds React style to our `.eslintrc.` These rules were authored by @nkt

Should we keep these rules separate from our base `.eslintrc` or is it fine to put them in here?

title: eslint react plugin
body:
[There is a great plugin](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react) for eslint which adds some validation rules for React.
Bellow rules according yours style guide:

``` json
"react/display-name": 0,
"react/jsx-boolean-value": 2,
"react/jsx-quotes": [2, "double"],
"react/jsx-no-undef": 2,
"react/jsx-sort-props": 0,
"react/jsx-sort-prop-types": 0,
"react/jsx-uses-react": 2,
"react/jsx-uses-vars": 2,
"react/no-did-mount-set-state": [2, "allow-in-func"],
"react/no-did-update-set-state": 2,
"react/no-multi-comp": 2,
"react/no-unknown-property": 2,
"react/prop-types": 2,
"react/react-in-jsx-scope": 2,
"react/self-closing-comp": 2,
"react/wrap-multilines": 2,
"react/sort-comp": [2, {
  "order": [
    "displayName",
    "mixins",
    "statics",
    "propTypes",
    "getDefaultProps",
    "getInitialState",
    "componentWillMount",
    "componentDidMount",
    "componentWillReceiveProps",
    "shouldComponentUpdate",
    "componentWillUpdate",
    "componentWillUnmount",
    "/^on.+$/",
    "/^get.+$/",
    "/^render.+$/",
    "render"
  ]
}]
```

title: Incorrect assumption about `let` vs `var`
body:
In your References section, you tell developers to only use `let` in their code. This is a poor choice that can lead to problems. `let` is not a replacement for `var`, it is a tool to be used alongside it. First off, using `var` to indicate a variable has functional scope is a very clear signal as to the life expectancy of that variable whereas using `let` is weaker. Functionally they are the same, of course, until you start refactoring and your `let` declared variables start disappearing.

Rather than advise developers to use only `let`, advise them to use `var` when the intent of the variable is to live in the full scope of the function and use `let` when the scope of the variable is meant to be limited (such as conditionals or loops, or even explicit `let` scopes).

For reference: http://davidwalsh.name/for-and-against-let

like https://github.com/suan/vim-instant-markdown from breaking syntax.

title: Packages publishing
body:
Did you think about describing right way for package publishing?
At least for node packages we are using `dependencies`, but for frontend packages, for exam-ple React, we should use `peerDependencies` for avoiding dependencies duplication.
Also there is no best practice for publishing packages that requires polyfills.

title: [conditionals] clarify conditionals. fixes #336
body: fixes #336

title: ToBoolean abstract operation not used in comparison operator
body:
Hey there! Really appreciate the contribution, especially with the newest additions in regards to ES6.

I did want to point out that the https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#comparison-operators--equality section is a little misleading as the ToBoolean abstract operator is not used in either the `==` or `===` equality operator as you mentioned

> Comparison operators are evaluated using coercion with the ToBoolean method and always follow these simple rules

The spec is pretty clear which abstract operators are used to coerce type during these comparisons as you can see here: http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-11.9.3

I confirmed this with Kyle Simpson who has a extensive chapter on Coercion in his You Don't Know JS series: https://github.com/getify/You-Dont-Know-JS/blob/master/scope%20%26%20closures/ch4.md

Here is the thread I had with Kyle: https://github.com/getify/You-Dont-Know-JS/issues/435

According to the spec, what is actually occurring during the comparison is a little more verbose that what should be explained in your guide, but I will leave that up to you guys since you've written such an awesome guide to date :)

Hope I helped in any form. Thanks!

title: [Question] Wrapping conditionals
body:
Is there any prefered way of doing this kind of things?

``` javascript
if ((a == b) && (c > d * 2))
```

``` javascript
if (a == b && c > d * 2)
```

``` javascript
if ((a == b) && (c > (d * 2)))
```

etc
